title: Marouane Fellaini becoming Jose Mourinho's Special One after years as the player Man United fans love to hate
text:

Manchester United 's Marouane Fellaini has reinvented himself in the eyes of their fans this season. 
Midfielder Fellaini was criticised after conceding a late penalty at Everton and was even booed by United fans at Old Trafford. But within the space of a few weeks, Fellaini has got the supporters back onside after proving himself an invaluable part of the Jose Mourinho ’s squad. 
Now, the Belgian has revealed his connection with Mourinho was first formed when the Special One called him immediately after taking charge last summer. 
Fellaini said: “I’ve always had good relationships with managers. But with Jose I have a great relationship. I respect him, he gives me confidence. Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Jose Mourinho reveals Manchester United's summer transfer plans Share this video Watch Next 
"He called me and texted me on my holiday to give me confidence and say he trusts me. When a manager calls you and says you are part of his plans and that he trusts you, then you will give everything for him.” 
It is that sort of belief that helped Fellaini earlier in the season, and he is honest enough to hold up his hands to his mistake for bringing down Everton’s Idrissa Gueye as United dropped two points. 
Mourinho made a point of bringing Fellaini on in their next Premier League game against Tottenham to show his support while the fans jeered. Our John Cross (left) spoke to Fellaini about his Man United career 
The manager promised he “would always have his protection.” 
And the Belgian has also become Mourinho’s “go-to man” when he needs to send somebody on to try to win a game or see one out. 
“That’s football. Ok, I made a mistake,” said Fellaini. “I’m the first to know that I did. It was a mistake. That’s it, done, next game. 
“There was a problem with the fans booing me after the Everton game, but after that it was done. When I make a mistake I know it, when I do well I know it, when I do bad I know it. 
“I am honest and I don’t need people to tell me. I had a lot of things in my life and my career, so I don’t need to keep thinking about a mistake. It’s part of football. Here's Fellaini actually holding his hands up over THAT penalty at Goodison (Photo: Liverpool Echo) 
“When the manager asks me to do things on the pitch, I will try to do it and try to do it well. If the manager tells me something there is a reason so I do it. I am a team player. I know I am not a player who will dribble past five players and score, but I know my quality. 
“I do my job, if the manager is happy that is the most important thing and then my team-mates. There is always someone talking because Manchester United is a big club. 
“I am used to it, so I don’t listen any more. I do my job and when the manager gives me a chance to play, I give everything.” 
Fellaini is a contrast to what you see on the pitch. Many United fans fumed over the signing of Fellaini from Everton for £27m (Photo: Getty) Read More Mourinho 'to reduce training intensity' because of Man United's stacked schedule 
He is polite, softly spoken and very respectful as he talks glowingly about Zlatan Ibrahimovic and Paul Pogba. 
He laughs about people obsessing his hair, teasingly posting a picture of him in the barber’s earlier this week when actually he was just getting his afro tidied up. 
But there is also an underlying determination and seriousness about being successful. 
They face Watford on Saturday, and it was in the reverse fixture in September when Mourinho probably hit his lowest point. 
United lost 3-1 that day, and Mourinho was clearly struggling. United get a chance to avenge September's 3-1 defeat at Watford this weekend (Photo: Getty) Read More Man United to immortalise record scorer Rooney with own exhibit in club museum 
Now, five months, on they have reached the League Cup final, are making a push for the top four and are still in the Europa League and FA Cup. 
Fellaini said: “Yeah, we are on a great run. We haven’t lost for three months in the league. We lost (the EFL Cup semi-final's second leg) against Hull, but we are in the final so it’s good – we have to keep going. 
“When a new manager comes in he has to find his balance, now he has it so we have to keep going, keep fighting and work hard. Everyone wants to show himself. We have a lot of confidence and everyone wants to play, so it’s good for the team. United are pushing for a top-four finish after a 15-game unbeaten league run (Photo: Man Utd via Getty Images) Read More Zlatan admits he "feels the pressure" of playing for United despite stunning career 
“If you want to win things all the staff have to be together, a family. We try to do that and and now we’e had time it is more intense. It’s shown that we are strong. 
“A club like Manchester United, they have to play Champions League so the minimum is to be top four. At the beginning of the season we wanted to be Champions. That’s normal at this club. 
“But we lost points, we drew a lot. Games like Stoke and Hull and Burnley at home, we should win but we didn’t. Six points is a lot to drop in the Premier League. 
"We have to win some games now and keep going to the end of the season.” poll loading Man United fans! Do you like Marouane Fellaini now? 0+ VOTES SO FAR
